column3: b'SO YOU WANT TO BE A 19th CENTURY HEROINE'
column7: b'The Tebenna, an Etruscan mantle, evolved into this garment perhaps worn most strikingly by John Belushi'
column8: b'This wrestler nicknamed his daughter born in August 2001 Pebbles'
column9: b"If you have this adjective before your name, like Nell or Eva, don't bother planning for your old age"
column10: b"What's now officially called the Central Park Wildlife Center is probably better-known by this name"
column11: b'Proverbially, this pungent bulb "makes a man wink, drink & stink"'
column12: b'This state that acts as a conjunction between Nevada & Washington has an abbreviation that is a conjunction'
column13: b'Oscar Mayer could tell you that this is the city the Etruscans called Felsina'
column14: b"Fatally, American groupie Nancy Spungen was this British punk rocker's girlfriend"
column15: b'Your job options include teacher & this related job of the heroines in "Jane Eyre" & "Vanity Fair"'
column16: b'Central Park has a statue of King Wladyslaw II Jagiello of this country, who was also Grand Duke of Lithuania'
column17: b"It's the Belgian province bordering the Netherlands that's famous for originating a smelly cheese"
column18: b'The abbreviation of this state is also an abbreviation for the largest city in California'
column19: b'Along with the Borgia apartments, the Etruscan Museum is one of the top attractions in this 109-acre country'
column20: b'She owns the St. Louis Rams'
column21: b'Even if you\'re 27 & still single, like Anne in this author\'s "Persuasion", your life may not be over'
column22: b'(Sofia of the Clue Crew jogs through Central Park.) I\'m running around the reservoir now named for this first lady, who lived nearby and used to go jogging here'
column23: b'This cartoon character\'s big screen credits include "For Scent-imental Reasons" & "Heaven Scent"'
column24: b'Show me that the abbreviation for this state means the habits of a predictable criminal'
column25: b"The wolf in the Capitoline Wolf statue may be Etruscan; these 2 babies she's suckling were added around 1509"
column26: b'This actor gave a speech for Harvard roommate Al Gore at the 2000 Democratic Convention'
column27: b'Like Gertrude in this author\'s "The Europeans", go ahead & marry a relative (it might get you out of your house, too)'
column28: b'In the 1953 film "The Band Wagon" Fred Astaire & this leggy partner were "Dancing In The Dark" through Central Park'
column29: b'The strong odor of this semi-aquatic rodent gives it its name'
column30: b'When abbreviated before the number 47, this state becomes an assault weapon'
column31: b'A 1927 visit to Etruscan sites inspired this author of "The Plumed Serpent" to write "Etruscan Places"'
column32: b'M.C. Hammer earned his nickname from his resemblance to this "Hammerin\'" home run king'
column33: b'Unlike Dorothea in this George Eliot book, marry for love, not intellectual compatibility'
column34: b"Cleopatra's Needle is a short walk from this Egyptian Temple in the Metropolitan Museum of Art"
column35: b'The only film ever released in "Odorama", it shares its name with a synthetic fabric popular in the 1970s'
column36: b'State whose abbreviation is also a cabinet department that was formed in 1989'
column73: b'This South Carolina city that gave us a popular dance in the 1920s was the site of the first opera in America in 1735'
column74: b'When making this classic Chinese soup, be sure to remove the twigs, feathers & insects first'
column75: b"On New Year's Day 2002, this school's Seminoles beat Virginia Tech 30-17 to win the Gator Bowl"
column76: b'The A.M.E. in A.M.E. Church stands for African Methodist this'
column77: b'The four-color problem relates to the minimum number of colors needed for this cartographic item'
column78: b'These peptide hormones in the brain reduce the sensation of pain'
column79: b'In 1750 theater was banned in this then-colonial capital as a form of Mass. entertainment'
column80: b"To enjoy this national Swiss dish, you'd better like cheese, lots of it, melted in wine"
column81: b"In 2001 Brian Cappelletto won this game's World Championship with words like vozhd for 50 points & jerrid for 44"
column82: b"Less than 20% of all Muslims are Shi'ites or of other groups; the rest belong to this branch"
column83: b'Ferdinand von Lindemann proved the problem of "squaring" this with compass & ruler was impossible'
column84: b'2-word term for the consumer, for whom a computer is ultimately designed'
column85: b'Some of the earliest surviving colonial portraits are of Richard & Increase, members of this family'
column86: b'The seafood in this Mexican dish is "cooked" not by heat, but by the acid in lime juice'
column87: b'In 1993 she became the first woman from Ukraine to win the world figure skating championships'
column88: b"Founded by & named for a Persian prophet, this religion flourished during Persia's Achaemenian empire"
column89: b'(Cheryl of the Clue Crew peruses a model train hobbyist\'s fantasy setup.) If train "A" leaves at 3:00 at 60 mph, & train "B" leaves at 5:00 at 90 mph, this equation, d=rt, tells you when B passes A'
column90: b'This Baja California port city is known as "Yellowtail Capital of the World"'
column91: b'Meaning "tobacco peddler", it\'s the title of a 1708 Ebenezer Cooke poem & a 1960 John Barth novel about Cooke'
column92: b'This Greek dish typically consists of layers of eggplant & ground lamb or beef topped with a white sauce'
column93: b"At Wimbledon 2000, Venus Williams expressed appreciation for this 1957 & '58 champion"
column94: b"Traditionally, in Judaism a ram's horn called this is blown at the end of Yom Kippur"
column95: b'To apply relativity to the cosmos, Einstein introduced a term called the "cosmological" this'
column96: b'The U.S. conducted nuclear tests on this atoll in the Marshall Islands from 1948 to 1958'
column97: b"James Alexander, whose doggerel contributed to this publisher's arrest, helped defend him as a lawyer"
column98: b'On an Italian menu this term describes pasta with a sauce of eggs, cream, parmesan & bacon'
column99: b'The last British athlete to win the Olympic decathlon, he won it back-to-back in 1980 & 1984'
column100: b'Joseph Smith translated the Book of Mormon from gold plates revealed to him by an angel named this'
column101: b'This Frenchman\'s "last theorem", stated in 1637, was proved by Andrew Wiles in the 1990s'
column102: b'John Keats wrote a poem about this handsome Greek whose youth was preserved by eternal sleep'
column134: b'Number of males who served as British PM in the 1990s plus Oscars won by Tom Hanks plus protons in a helium nucleus'
